p.s: It is often discussed wetherwhether Shakespeare is important for today's young people or not.
there are arguments for both sides of view.
On the one hand, Shakespeare and his achievements are national mnuments, especially for Britains.
His described topics are timeless and still relevant today and are used in many new stories.
Furthermore, he created many new words and sayings, for instance All that glitters is not gold, that are still popular today.
So he is very important for the British and the general history.
On the other hand, his writings are 400 years old, this very difficult to understand for native and second-language englishEnglish speakers.
That causes that most of the students do not like to read his poems and dramas.
Moreover, only a few, mostly older people, use the sayings he invented and so most of them are not known by young people.
Last but not least, there exist many other stories today that are easier to understand and nevertheless interesting and important, maybe written about the same theme as Shakespeare's writings.
So altogether, Shakespeare is not relevant anymore, sometimes even disliked by the youth.
But that is no reason to forget him and his writings because they are still actual and also beautiful written.
So maybe the interest of young people could be awakened when the texts are teached in a more interactive way and then today's englishEnglish.
For example, performing the stories on stage at school or simply letting the students writing poems on their own, and everyone would have fun while talking about Shakespeare immediatlyimmediately.
So the cars for the shrinking relevance of Shakespeare are not his texts but the way the young people get in touch with them.
